'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'WILLOW, Alaska (KTUU) - Five-time Iditarod champion Dallas Seavey is grieving the deaths of two sled dogs from his kennel that were killed in a crash on Friday. Seavey, who runs a sled dog tour company out of Talkeetna, took to social media on Wednesday to announce the deaths, which he said resulted from a collision between one of his sled dog teams and a snowmachine on the Denali Highway. “There’s not much that bothers me more than seeing a dog in pain like that,” Seavey said in a phone interview. The champion musher said he and two others were running dog teams of nine, 10, and 12, respectively, at the time of the crash. He said the fellow musher leading the team of nine was training when a snowmachine speeded into his team, resulting in the two deaths. Seavey wrote the aftermath of the crash resulted in three dogs — Whopper, Sigfried, and Houdini — with severe injuries and amputated limbs. “It happens, but when it has never happened to you, it seems very distant, if that makes sense, it almost seems hypothetical,” Seavey said of this type of collision. “And I’ve been mushing dogs for 30-plus years.” Seavey said the snowmachines were traveling very quickly. “And the first one went by him without issue. I mean, it’s the Denali Highway, it’s pretty dang wide. And you know, he was well lit, it was a bit of a turn, but you could probably see 200-250 yards from the point that we got impacted. The second snowmachine came around the corner ... and just T-boned right into the team,” Seavey said. Seavey said the impact was so great it launched his fellow musher off the sled while the snowmachine ricocheted and traveled about 60 yards before coming to a stop. “All three have a long road to partial recovery in front of them and in Houdini’s case, with a major surgery still ahead, a positive outcome is far from guaranteed,” Seavey wrote on Facebook. The Alaska State Troopers are continuing to investigate a dogsled-snowmachine crash, with AST’s Tim DeSpain writing the case “appears” to be the same incident as the one Seavey posted about. Troopers say no citations have been issued in the crash so far. Once Seavey caught up to the dogs, he said that the snowmachiner smelled like alcohol and was not speaking clearly. Copyright 2023 KTUU. All rights reserved.'}]

0.88}}}, 'overall_burstiness': 0, 'writing_stats': {}, 'subclass': {'ai': {}, 'human': {}, 'mixed': {}}, 'result_message': 'Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'FAIRBANKS, Alaska (KTVF) - A new overnight warming center is in store for the Golden Heart city, propped up by the nonprofit HopeLink. Fairbanks averages lows of about 14 degrees below Fahrenheit from December to February, and according to the Mayo Clinic, it only takes a wind chill of about 16 below to cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes. Yet Fairbanks offers little when it comes to low-barrier places for the city’s homeless population to escape Interior Alaska’s bone-chilling temperatures, even temporarily. That, however, is changing. HopeLink will lease the Hannah Solomon building from the Fairbanks Native Association for the hours of 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. to run their seven-day-a-week operation. The center will be staffed with two peer support specialists during those hours. The organization is still getting its footing and training employees, according to Vice President Jennifer Jolis, but is aiming to open its doors some time in January. The new nonprofit diverges from the scope of a full-fledged shelter and will instead give people a short-term location to get out of the cold. “There will not be beds or mats. There will be comfortable chairs. There will be coffee. There will be some food. There will be charging units, all the things that people need,” Jolis said at a Thursday meeting of the Fairbanks Housing and Homeless Coalition, “but most importantly, it will be a warm place and it will be a warm, safe place.” People will not be permitted to drink, do drugs or act violently while at the center, but there’s not much by way of conditions for entry, and sobriety is not a requirement. In other words, it is low barrier. “That means people who are incapacitated in some way can still come,” Jolis said. Jo Woodward, who once dealt with homelessness herself, said she is thrilled to see this kind of development in the community. “People need people,” Woodward told Newscenter Fairbanks, “and I believe Fairbanks has really been blessed this Christmas because there are so many programs now that have never been available before,” she added. The new organization’s purpose addresses a hole in social services that’s bordered but not filled by the missions of other, existing organizations in town. HopeLink’s purview matches some of what another warming center, No Limits, currently provides. What separates them is time. No Limits, located at 253 Romans Way in South Fairbanks, primarily offers a low-barrier heated space during daytime hours, open from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Monday through Friday and 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. At Thursday’s meeting, No Limits Director Roscoe Britton did say his organization recently began admitting a regular group of six to stay overnight, but that’s not the norm. “So far that’s worked out pretty good and that’s something that’s needed in the community,” he said. Like HopeLink, the Rescue Mission also lets people inside their doors overnight, but unlike HopeLink, the shelter has bars for entry that include sobriety. Meanwhile, the Fairbanks Sobering Center has the opposite prerequisite, with people seeking those services not admitted unless actively under the influence of drugs or alcohol. HopeLink, then, checkmarks a different combination of boxes than any other local organization by staying open overnight and allowing people inside, sober or not. Copyright 2023 KTVF. All rights reserved.'}]

'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'FAIRBANKS, Alaska (KTVF) - CORRECTION: The Alaska Department of Transportation and Public Facilities tries to plow Priority One roads in 12 hours. However, Priority Two roads can take as long as 18 hours after the end of a storm, and Priority Three roads up to 24 hours. ORIGINAL STORY: The Golden Heart City saw at least six inches of snow accumulate on Tuesday and Wednesday, December 13 and 14, which means snow plows can be seen traversing interior roads. “If people are patient, then that keeps everybody safe,” said John Perreault, Public Information Officer with the Alaska Department of Transportation and Public Facilities (DOT). When snow hits the roads in Interior Alaska, so do the snow plows from the DOT and the City of Fairbanks. The DOT is responsible for large and busy roads in the Fairbanks area. These include first priority routes like the Mitchell and Steese Expressways and the Johansen Expressway. Second priority roads for DOT to plow include Peger Road and Airport Way. On Wednesday, ten department plows entered the roads to clear accumulated snow, some including sanders. “On a day like today, we’ll have as many plows as we can get people into out. We have some groups that go out in up to six plows, so we can plow priority one highways in one pass,” explained Perreault. When on a route with a snow plow, the department recommends drivers keep their distance. “In many cases you’ll see a big green sign on the back that says ‘Keep Back 200 Feet.’ That’s recommended for your safety as well as to make sure that our operations can be done cleanly, without any interruption,” he said. Be sure to allow as much space as possible for a plow if sharing a road going in the opposite direction, according to Perreault. “Not only are they plowing, but often, especially in intersections, they’re going to be laying down gravel as well in order to assist traction for vehicles moving through those high-traffic areas.” When engaged plowing, these vehicles travel at most 35 miles an hour, to keep the snow they’re moving under control. However, the DOT does not recommend passing active plows while headed in the same direction. “There is snow that goes off in both directions, even a little bit to the left when they have an angled plow to the right. It’s recommended that you just wait for the plow, be patient and get somewhere safe,” Perreault said. DOT’s goal is to have all of its roads of responsibility plowed by 12 hours after a storm ends. More information about the DOT’s plowing operations can be found here, and City of Fairbanks plowing information here. This story was updated on December 15 to more accurately reflect the DOT’s timeline for plowing roads in the Fairbanks area. Copyright 2023 KTVF. All rights reserved.'}]
